channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Do you love customers? Senior Perl Developer with a product focus, London
item.description: Ever find yourself wishing you could see meaningful impact on users from your work? Trapped in a company with long release cycles and dubious release dates? Wish your ideas for product improvement didnâ€™t keep disappearing in to the Project Managerâ€™s backlog?

item.title: Independent thinkers required! Mid/Senior-level Developer for an innovative London company
item.description: Have you ever worked for a company with a micromanagement style, where a boss was constantly breathing down your neck? Do you hate spending more time in meetings about product requirements than actually getting on with building the product?

item.title: Perl Mongers of Wimbledon Common Are We - Perl Developer wanted in Wimbledon
item.description: Back in the day, the Wombles of Wimbledon collected rubbish. Nowadays, since the advent of motorised road sweepers, theyâ€™d be in need of a new profession. Perl Developer, perhaps? Our client is based in the heart of Wimbledon, under a mile away from the Common where the Wombles famously made their home.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Ansible
item.description: The beginning of a series on using Ansible for Configuration Management

item.title: Public nomination/election process of TPF board members
item.description: How to become a TPF board member?

item.title: 2018.09 Say Cheese.d
item.description: The regular weekly post with plenty of interesting links to articles, questions, Tweets, and more.

item.title: P5P update: Smarter Match
item.description: A change was not successful and was caught by tests of downstream code. Nothing to see here. Though I guess if CPAN was smoked using development code then this would have been caught earlier. Strangely I thought it was already smoked.

item.title: Perl 5 Porters Mailing List Summary: February 12th-18th
Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (zefram): Grant Report February 2018
Interviews with Perl hackers about life and work (2013-2015)
Announcing Plack::Middleware::StatsPerRequest
item.description: Some new code escaped the DarkPan and became free. Your help with tests is welcome!

item.title: The 3rd generation of DBIx::DataModel is on CPAN
item.description: DBIx::DataModel is an object-relational mapping (ORM) framework for building Perl abstractions. The article explains some of its advantages.

item.title: Setup your computer for CPAN-PRC
item.description: How to start working on the CPAN Pull Request using Docker or locally using Perlbrew and friends.

item.title: Module::FromPerlVer
item.description: A module that installs other modules compatible with the running perl.

item.title: New defaults for Perl Linting in Vim's Ale Plugin
Strings in YAML - To Quote or not to Quote
item.description: Tina continues to explain the details of YAML and her own work on the YAML processors.

item.title: Start writing the Markua parser in Perl
item.description: Markua is a Makrdown-inspired language for writing books created by LeanPub. In this article series I am going to explain how I build a Markua Parser in Perl. I need it to make it easier to generate ebooks from the content of the Perl Maven web site.

item.title: Marpa Debugging
item.description: Sometimes you need to debug even code using Marpa. How can you do that?

item.title: How does traceroute work?
item.description: ... and the Perl module that implements traceroute.

item.title: Exponential Backoff in Service Startup
item.description: Wait more and more time before trying to launch a service.

item.title: Why does this code not work? (split, array slice)
item.description: A problematic piece of code and a solution. If you would like to see it.

item.title: Full Disk, What's Next?
item.description: A mix of Shell and Perl code to find the big files that take up a lot of disk space.

item.title: Real World Perl: Analyze Chrome's heap
Moosilla?
item.description: John's frenzied pace of postings about Moose and DistZilla continues. Check out his blogs for the newest!

item.title: The Perl Conference Newsletter: 2/28/18
item.description: Last Call for Tutorial Session; Last Round for Speaker Submissions open; Event Registration; Room Reservation; Sponsorship; You can also subscribe to the Perl Conference Newsletter.

item.title: #345 - Plenty of posts
item.description:
Hi there,

Besides the ongoing blogs of John Scolese, in the past few days fREW Schmidt has also posted every day. Is there a wakening? I'd love to see more people getting active again telling about their use cases of Perl. You do still use Perl, don't you?

In other news my crowdfunding campaign to update the Perl tutorial has passed the 25% mark. To tell the truth I was hoping that a lot more of you would support it by now. Not because you need it, but because you think it can help future Perl developers. Go ahead support the project.

Enjoy the week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
